stream_context.summary: Kaze focused on two parallel tasks: finishing a ground-up rewrite of Mario 64’s sound engine and blocking-out the gigantic ‘Overworld’ map for Return to Yoshi’s Island, while fielding chat questions about design philosophy, team progress, legal concerns, release timing and personal life.

development_findings.summary: Kaze rewrote Mario 64’s entire sound engine: it now runs ~80 % faster, uses one-quarter of the code, needs far less RAM and supports 32 simultaneous notes (up from 16).
development_findings.quote: The sound engine is now around 80 % faster than vanilla… We support 32 notes instead of 16.

development_findings.summary: The new engine eliminates a long-standing vanilla bug that prevented adding extra sound effects; once the remaining allocation/DMA work is done, the team can freely add new SFX.
development_findings.quote: In vanilla…if you try to add sound effects, it doesn’t really work. I never knew why, but I’m sure that my rework doesn’t have that issue anymore.

development_findings.summary: No further public demos are planned; the next playable build will be the finished game.
development_findings.quote: I don’t think there will be another demo. The next release will be the full game.

development_findings.summary: The Overworld will be the biggest level in the hack, containing roughly 30 stars and multiple themed sub-areas (Yoshi Village, Mountain Village, Flower Farm, Treehouses, Wool Warehouse, Boshi’s Target Practice, Bowser entrance).
development_findings.quote: This is the overworld…This level will have like 30 stars or something like that.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is experimenting with terrain scale and natural ‘buffers’ (trees, mountains) to separate Bowser’s area from Yoshi settlements and avoid large empty expanses.
development_findings.quote: There needs to be a good bit of space between them… But also, we don’t want a lot of empty space.

development_findings.summary: Post-game state will persist; after defeating Bowser the world stays ‘saved’ so players can continue exploring instead of being forced back to a pre-final-boss state.
development_findings.quote: I want the player to save the world and then be like, yep, this is the world now…You saved it.

development_findings.summary: The Overworld already has 12–15 bespoke music tracks that will cross-fade between regions, made possible by the upgraded audio engine.
development_findings.quote: The song is going to fade whenever you walk to a different area, so the overworld is going to be insanely full and sprawling with music.

development_findings.summary: Kaze developed a new RNG algorithm that draws on real-world entropy (e.g., console temperature); a video explaining the method is in production.
development_findings.quote: The video is about…finding a new RNG algorithm that uses real-world entropy.

development_findings.summary: Most textures are now custom; to pursue a ‘legal’ standalone release every remaining Nintendo texture will eventually be replaced, likely requiring additional texture artists.
development_findings.quote: In the end I probably will have to make every texture custom…if I actually do want to make this a legal game.

development_findings.summary: Level production workflow: Kaze always sketches levels on paper/Photoshop first, then blocks them out in Blender, continually resizing until the scale feels right.
development_findings.quote: I always sketch my level first.

context_findings.summary: Kaze lives in Canada (moved from Europe in Nov 2021) and expects to qualify for Canadian citizenship in two months.
context_findings.quote: I live in Canada now…in two months I can take the citizenship test and then I will be a Canadian citizen.

context_findings.summary: He holds a regular (non-senior) programming day job, relies on sponsor videos for extra income and admits he ‘could really use more money’.
context_findings.quote: Nope, I’m literally just a normal programmer at my day job… I could really use more money though.

context_findings.summary: Time management philosophy: most people ‘waste’ free time; Kaze channels his into development, making the workload appear ‘insane’ from the outside.
context_findings.quote: If you think about your day-to-day, I’m sure you’ll find that you waste most of your free time…and that’s why you don’t have time to do stuff like this.

context_findings.summary: He avoids announcing release dates to minimize legal risk; the game must launch in a window when Nintendo is quiet to reduce the chance of a takedown.
context_findings.quote: I can’t release this around the same time as Nintendo releases anything…because if I do they will literally kill me.

context_findings.summary: Kaze shows mild frustration with community projects (Hackmari64) that ignore his optimizations or call his code ‘too hard to debug’.
context_findings.quote: They kept complaining that they can’t have my code because my code is too difficult to understand… Now I’m a bit of a hater.

biobak.summary: Producing large numbers of custom textures and sent Kaze a Blender UV-mapping plug-in that sped up today’s terrain work.
biobak.quote: Biobak is making a lot of custom textures…but I probably will have to make every texture custom.

biobak.summary: Still has ‘so many levels to rework’, indicating an ongoing, substantial workload.
biobak.quote: There’s still so many levels for Biobak to rework.

zeina.summary: Personal/professional overlap: Zeina (Kaze’s spouse) visited Germany about a year after they met; they later married and now both live in Canada.
zeina.quote: She came to Germany around like a year after we started talking and then I moved to Canada.

key_stories.title: A New Sound Engine
key_stories.summary: Feeling limited by Mario 64’s original audio code, Kaze decided to rebuild it from scratch. The rewrite slashed processing time, memory use and code size while doubling polyphony.
key_stories.challenge: Vanilla engine was slow, memory-hungry and broke when adding new SFX.
key_stories.process: Reverse-engineered original, rewrote subsystems, tackled allocation and DMA, iteratively fixed bugs during streams.
key_stories.outcome: Engine now 80 % faster, supports 32 notes, frees resources for complex music and extra sound effects; remaining bugs are being ironed out.
key_stories.key_quote: The sound engine is now around 80 % faster than vanilla and we support 32 notes instead of 16.

key_stories.title: Randomness Reinvented
key_stories.summary: While preparing a sponsored video, Kaze discovered the console’s temperature could seed randomness, leading to a more authentic RNG routine for the hack and future projects.
key_stories.challenge: Standard RNG in Mario 64 isn’t very random and is predictable.
key_stories.process: Analyzed existing algorithm, experimented with entropy sources, integrated temperature data, drafted educational video.
key_stories.outcome: New RNG function implemented; explanatory video and thumbnail now in production.
key_stories.key_quote: The video is about finding a new RNG algorithm that uses real-world entropy as well.

key_stories.title: Reshaping the Overworld
key_stories.summary: Early block-outs of the massive Overworld felt empty and poorly scaled. Kaze iteratively added mountains, tree lines and villages, even scaling the whole area down by 20 %.
key_stories.challenge: Bowser’s entrance and Yoshi villages were too close, creating large flat dead-space.
key_stories.process: Consulted sketches, added geographic buffers (mountains, trees with hammocks), resized meshes, introduced new landmarks like a Wool Warehouse.
key_stories.outcome: Layout now feels denser and better separated; visual polish still Placeholder but flow is established.
key_stories.key_quote: This still feels big and flat… Maybe it would be better if I actually had some proper mountain region here.
